greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of obtuse integer triangles with perimeter n.
comment: An integer triangle [A070080(k) <= A070081(k) <= A070082(k)] is obtuse iff A070085(k) < 0.
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Obtuse Triangle.
example: For n=14 there are A005044(14)=4 integer triangles: [2,6,6], [3,5,6], [4,4,6] and [4,5,5]; two of them are obtuse, as 3^2+5^2<36=6^2 and 4^2+4^2<36=6^2, therefore a(14)=2.
mathematica: Table[Sum[Sum[(1 - Sign[Floor[(i^2 + k^2)/(n - i - k)^2]]) Sign[Floor[(i + k)/(n - i - k + 1)]], {i, k, Floor[(n - k)/2]}], {k, Floor[n/3]}], {n, 100}] (* _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, May 12 2019 *)
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 05 2002
